For any real number T > 0 and any function f from the additive circle of T to a normed additive commutative group with a real normed space, the integral of f over (t, t + T] equals the integral of its restriction to the additive circle of T.

type:
‚àÄ (T : ‚Ñù) [hT : Fact (0 < T)] {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] (t : ‚Ñù)
  (f : AddCircle T ‚Üí E), ‚à´ (a : ‚Ñù) in t..t + T, f ‚Üëa = ‚à´ (b : AddCircle T), f b
name: AddCircle.intervalIntegral_preimage
docString: For any real number T > 0 and any function f from the additive circle of T to a normed additive commutative group with a real normed space, the integral of f over (t, t + T] equals the integral of its restriction to the additive circle of T.

This theorem is known as the Cauchy formula for the derivative of a holomorphic function. It states that for any normed additive commutative group `E`, any normed space over `‚ÑÇ` with `E` as base, and any complete space `E`, given an open set `U` in the complex plane, complex numbers `c` and `w‚ÇÄ`, a real number `R`, and a function `f` from complex numbers to `E`, if the closed ball centered at `c` with radius `R` is a subset of `U` and `f` is differentiable on `U` and `w‚ÇÄ` is in the open ball centered at `c` with radius `R`, then the integral of `f z` divided by `(z - w‚ÇÄ)¬≤` around the circle centered at `c` with radius `R`, scaled by the multiplicative inverse of `2œÄi`, equals the derivative of `f` at `w‚ÇÄ`. This is a crucial property of holomorphic functions and serves as the foundation for many results in complex analysis.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {U : Set ‚ÑÇ},
  IsOpen U ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {c w‚ÇÄ : ‚ÑÇ} {R : ‚Ñù} {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E},
      Metric.closedBall c R ‚äÜ U ‚Üí
        DifferentiableOn ‚ÑÇ f U ‚Üí
          w‚ÇÄ ‚àà Metric.ball c R ‚Üí
            ((2 * ‚ÜëReal.pi * Complex.I)‚Åª¬π ‚Ä¢ ‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, R), ((z - w‚ÇÄ) ^ 2)‚Åª¬π ‚Ä¢ f z) = deriv f w‚ÇÄ
name: Complex.two_pi_I_inv_smul_circleIntegral_sub_sq_inv_smul_of_differentiable
docString: This theorem is known as the Cauchy formula for the derivative of a holomorphic function. It states that for any normed additive commutative group `E`, any normed space over `‚ÑÇ` with `E` as base, and any complete space `E`, given an open set `U` in the complex plane, complex numbers `c` and `w‚ÇÄ`, a real number `R`, and a function `f` from complex numbers to `E`, if the closed ball centered at `c` with radius `R` is a subset of `U` and `f` is differentiable on `U` and `w‚ÇÄ` is in the open ball centered at `c` with radius `R`, then the integral of `f z` divided by `(z - w‚ÇÄ)¬≤` around the circle centered at `c` with radius `R`, scaled by the multiplicative inverse of `2œÄi`, equals the derivative of `f` at `w‚ÇÄ`. This is a crucial property of holomorphic functions and serves as the foundation for many results in complex analysis.

For any normed additive commutative group E over the complex numbers, any function f from n-tuples of complex numbers to E, any real constants C and R with positive entries, and any n-tuple c of complex numbers, if the norm of f composed with the torus map with parameters c and R is bounded by C, then the norm of the integral of f over the n-dimensional complex torus with radii R is bounded by (2œÄ)^n * C * ‚àè(R_i), where R_i denote the entries of R.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {f : (Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) ‚Üí E} {c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ}
  {R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {C : ‚Ñù},
  (‚àÄ (Œ∏ : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù), ‚Äñf (torusMap c R Œ∏)‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí
    ‚Äñ‚àØ (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) in T(c, R), f x‚Äñ ‚â§ ((2 * Real.pi) ^ n * Finset.univ.prod fun i => |R i|) * C
name: norm_torusIntegral_le_of_norm_le_const
docString: For any normed additive commutative group E over the complex numbers, any function f from n-tuples of complex numbers to E, any real constants C and R with positive entries, and any n-tuple c of complex numbers, if the norm of f composed with the torus map with parameters c and R is bounded by C, then the norm of the integral of f over the n-dimensional complex torus with radii R is bounded by (2œÄ)^n * C * ‚àè(R_i), where R_i denote the entries of R.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `‚ÑÇ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

  (‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, 0), f z) = 0
name: circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero
